title: Bearded Dragon Feeding Guide: Diet, Schedule & Nutrition
description: Complete feeding guide for bearded dragons covering insects, vegetables, feeding frequency by age, supplements, and common nutritional mistakes.
excerpt: Complete feeding guide for bearded dragons covering insects, vegetables, feeding frequency by age, supplements, and common nutritional mistakes.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Understanding Bearded Dragon Nutrition
content.content: Bearded dragons are omnivores with dietary needs that change dramatically as they grow. Feeding the right balance of insects and vegetables at each life stage is crucial for healthy growth, strong bones, and long-term wellbeing.

Nutritional requirements shift dramatically across bearded dragon ontogeny. Juvenile dragons require high protein for growth, while adults need fiber-rich vegetables for digestive health and weight management.

content.text: Feeding Schedule by Life Stage:

content.content: Dietary Transition: The shift from insect-heavy to vegetable-dominant diet is physiologically necessary. Adult bearded dragons fed juvenile-level protein develop obesity, hepatic lipidosis, and reproductive complications.
Nutritional diversity prevents deficiencies and promotes balanced amino acid profiles. Rotate multiple feeder species rather than relying on a single staple.

content.text: Nutritional Comparison of Common Feeder Insects:

content.content: Size Safety Rule: Feeder insects must not exceed the width between the bearded dragon's eyes. Oversized prey causes impaction, choking, and neurological damage from spinal pressure.
Adult bearded dragons require daily vegetables rich in calcium, fiber, and micronutrients. Target calcium:phosphorus ratios above 1.5:1 for optimal bone health.

content.text: Recommended Vegetables with Nutritional Data:

content.content: Preparation Method: Chop greens into pieces no larger than the space between the eyes. Bearded dragons do not chew thoroughly and require appropriately sized food to prevent choking.

content.text: Foods to Avoid or Limit:

content.content: Even with optimal UVB exposure, dietary supplementation prevents micronutrient deficiencies and supports metabolic function. Supplementation requirements vary by UVB quality and life stage.

content.text: Supplement Types and Application Schedule:

rows: Repashy Calcium Plus LoD, Arcadia EarthPro-A

content.content: Hypervitaminosis D3: Excessive vitamin D3 causes calcification of soft tissues (kidneys, heart, blood vessels). Limit D3 supplementation to 1-2x weekly. Bearded dragons with adequate UVB synthesize most D3 endogenously.
Gut-loading transfers nutrients from feeder insect diet to the predator. Insects should consume high-quality food 24-48 hours before being offered to bearded dragons.

content.text: Effective Gut-Loading Foods:

content.content: Critical Window: Insects metabolize gut contents within 48 hours. Feeders must be gut-loaded immediately before feeding to maximize nutritional transfer.
Bearded dragons exhibit low thirst drive and may not readily recognize standing water as drinkable. Multiple hydration strategies ensure adequate water intake.

content.text: Hydration Techniques and Effectiveness:

rows: Drip water on snout until licking

content.content: Bathing Myth: Soaking is not an effective hydration method. Bearded dragons do not absorb significant water through cloaca. Baths may assist with shedding but should not replace proper hydration techniques.

content.text: Frequent Mistakes and Corrections:

rows: Feeders no wider than eye spacing
Limit fruit to weekly treat only
Only wild-catch from verified safe areas

content.content: Proper nutrition manifests in observable physical and behavioral markers. Monitor these indicators to verify dietary adequacy.

content.text: Nutritional Health Indicators:

rows: Visible fat pads at tail base, ribs not prominent
Regular (3-5x weekly), formed, brown with white urate
Dull color, retained sheds, skin lesions
Stunted growth, failure to gain weight

content.content: Example rotation demonstrating dietary variety and appropriate adult feeding frequency.

content.text: 7-Day Meal Plan:

content.content: Nutritional Principle: Dietary variety is non-negotiable. No single food provides complete nutrition. Rotate greens daily and offer 3+ feeder species weekly for optimal health.
